oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Hallmarks of Country Music - Joe Stampley
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of an interview of Joe Stampley (musician). The interview is hosted by Rick Phillips (army sergeant/ radio host) for the Hallmarks of Country Music segment. The tape was recorded on an unidentified date.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Joe Stampley; Rick Phillips
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) I'm Still Loving You [excerpt] [featuring Joe Stampley radio spot for the Hallmarks of Country Music] (Joe Stampley) -- (00:20) How Lucky Can One Man be? [excerpt] (Joe Stampley) -- (00:32) Hallmarks tune [featuring Rick Phillips introduction voiceover] -- (01:14) The Army New Year's Resolution radio spot hosted by Rick Phillips -- (02:00) United States Customs commercial spot hosted by an unidentified voice -- (02:32) Too Far Gone (Joe Stampley) -- (05:10) Phillips introduces Stampley who reflects on his traveling work -- (06:57) All These Things (Joe Stampley) -- (11:03) Drug commercial spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (12:04) Phillips hosts a commercial break about military personal movements -- (12:42) Sometime (Joe Stampley) -- (15:52) Phillips and Stampley reflect on the time Stampley met Hank Williams; additionally, ""Take Time to Know Her"" is said to be telling a country message -- (17:47) Take Time to Know Her (Joe Stampley) -- (20:52) Airborne and Special Forces' openings radio spot hosted by Phillips -- (21:30) I'm Still Loving You (Joe Stampley) -- (24:23) Stampley expresses his appreciation to ""I'm Still Loving You,"" and Stampley and Phillips discusses Stampley's time with Paula Records -- (28:19) If You Touch Me (You've Got to Love Me) (Joe Stampley) -- (30:36) Feron Young reflects on his time in the military -- (31:43) Phillips hosts a radio spot about reenlistment in the military -- (32:16) How Lucky Can One Man be? (Joe Stampley) -- (34:27) ""How Lucky Can One Man be?"" is told by Stampley to have been recorded with the Uniques, and ""Not to Long Ago"" writer Merle Kilgore is reflected on by Stampley -- (35:47) Stampley reflects on his band and family -- (37:56) U.S.O. commercial spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (38:55) Bring it on Home to Your Woman (Joe Stampley) -- (40:52) P. X. check verification radio spot hosted by Phillips -- (41:30) Soul Song (Joe Stampley) -- (43:53) Stampley and Phillips discuss Stampley's first impression of ""Soul Song,"" and Stampley reflects on what he believes to be a hit -- (48:58) Take Me Home to Somewhere (Joe Stampley) -- (51:23) Dishonorable discharge radio spot hosted by an unidentified voice -- (52:00) Phillips asks Stampley to reflect on ""Most Beautiful Girl,"" and both say their goodbyes -- (53:19) Phillips performs a PX Money Saver program radio spot -- (53:47) Phillips performs his outro statement -- (54:10) Hallmarks outro tune ([Unidentified]) -- (55:36) Phillips introduces Ronnie Milsap -- (55:43) I'd be a Legend in My Time (Ronnie Milsap) -- (58:30) Milsap reflects on his time in college where he discovered his passion for music; additionally, Phillips questions Milsap's limitations based on his sight -- (1:00:00) Hallmarks outro tune ([Unidentified])
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:isPartOf: Insert is of program information. The insert features time stamps.
